CHAPTER XXXIII

AT the entreaty oi the townspeople‚ among whom he had first won fame, Saint Severinus came to Coma- genis. One of the nobles os King Feletheus had a son, a youth, who was wasted away by inveterate sickness and for whose burial preparations were already in progress. When the nobleman learned that Severinus was at Comagenis, he crossed the Danube and cast himself at his feet. Weeping‚ he said, “ I believe, man of God, that thy entreaty can procure from heaven a swift recovery for my son.’' Then Severinus offered prayer. The boy, who had been brought to him half- dead, straightway arose whole, to the amazement of his father, and forthwith returned home in perfect

health.
